Answer: That, when a psychiatrist takes the time needed to comprehensively evaluate a patient, can provide excellent quality care for most patients, and that this treatment can substantially improve the patient’s life.In spite of all of the endless negativity written here, I have been a psychiatrist in practice for thirty five years, and can attest personally that my patients appreciate the care I provideThat, when a psychiatrist takes the time needed to comprehensively evaluate a patient, can provide excellent quality care for most patients, and that this treatment can substantially improve the patient’s life.In spite of all of the endless negativity written here, I have been a psychiatrist in practice for thirty five years, and can attest personally that my patients appreciate the care I provide, the treatments I provide are adequately safe and effective.That we know quite a lot more than most people think.That because we can’t “prove” a lot of what goes on in the brain, we have no idea what we’re doing. That’s simply not true. We can’t prove a lot, that’s true, but research and experience has shown that we can help the people who show up in our offices.I have been treating patients in my practice here in Texas since 1985. Since that time, I have had the privilege of treating patients in multiple generations of the same family, as my patients get better, stay better, and refer their family and friends to me.I receive no money from anyone except my patients. For about three years, several years ago, a few pharmaceutical companies paid me to talk to other physicians about their medications. They all chose to stop having me speak for them, as I was open and honest about the pros and cons of their meds, as well as the advantages of other medications. I had been in practice for about twenty five years before any of them every asked me to speak, and haven’t done so for several years now.I am a volunteer professor at my local university, and have been active in my local and state psychiatric organizations. I know first hand how many of my colleagues are honest, compassionate people, and volunteer large amounts of time with these organizations to further promote access for the underprivileged, homeless, and low income population. Answer: As of yesterday it’s no longer “next”.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don’t know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejectiAs of yesterday it’s no longer “next”.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don’t know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejection. Even if the heart is rejected and the donor dies, what we learn from the process will enable us to succeed the next time. I reckon this will become the mainstream way we get spare parts by the end of the decade in an optimistic scenario, by the end of the next decade in the pessimistic one.Either way, the moment is as groundbreaking as December 3rd, 1967, when the first human heart ever was transplanted, ushering the era of organ transplants of today. That patient died after 18 days, I hope this guy does better.
